activity is enhanced obviously compared to alloyed Ir3RuO2 catalyst.

Received 00th January 20xx, Accepted 00th January 20xx
DOI: 10.1039/x0xx00000x
www.rsc.org/
Uncontinuously covered IrO2-RuO2@Ru electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reaction: How high activity and long-term durability can meet up in the synergistic and hybrid nanostructure? Guoqiang Li,a,b,c Songtao Li,d Junjie Ge,*a,b Changpeng Liua,b and Wei Xing*a,b
Here, we present our effort in simultaneously enhancing the intrinsic activity and improving the durability of catalysts based on Ir and Ru oxides. Through successful design and fabrication of the uncontinuously covered IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) supported structure, we are able to combine the high activity of RuO2 and the outstanding stability of IrO2. Specifically, the overpotential of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst at 10 mA cm-2 is only 281 mV, and the turnover frequency (TOF) values of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1), Ir3RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts are ca. 0.039, 0.023 and 0.017 s-1 at 1.55 V, respectively, indicating that IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits higher intrinsic activity and the active surface sites possess greater ability to generate oxygen. The excellent durability of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst is confirmed with the overpotential at 10 mA cm-2 positively shifts by only 16 mV after 3000 cycles through the accelerated durability tests. Remarkably, the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst exhibits huge advantage in saving the precious metals for water electrolysis. Hence, the supported Iridium-Ruthenium bimetallic oxides show huge potential towards active and stabilized application for oxygen evolution reaction in acidic media.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Nowadays, it is important to diversify the energy sources in order to promote the development of eco-friendly energy systems and avoid the emission of harmful by-products from fossil fuels.1 Hydrogen is an energy carrier with high energy density of 140 MJ kg-1 and water as the only combustion product, thereby is considered as an ideal candidate for replacing fossil fuels.2,3 Water electrolysis is
considered as one of the most practical and green ways to produce hydrogen using renewable energy sources.4-7 Although large scale production of hydrogen by water electrolysis is dominated by the alkaline electrolysis technology today, the solid polymer electrolyte (SPE) electrolyzer using proton exchange membrane has been considered the most promising system in the future, because of its higher energy efficiency and power density.7-9 However, sluggish reaction kinetics, high overpotential, and high cost of noble electrocatalysts on the anode side are the major obstacles in commercializing the SPE electrolyzer at present.9,10
Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) studies based on thermochemical density functional theory (DFT) have predicted the binding energy of a surface oxygen species as the activitycontrolling parameter, yielding a volcano type activity plot, with Ru and Ir oxides locate near the top.11-13 Therefore, Ru and Ir oxides are currently used as catalysts for the OER to provide enhanced catalytic activity and high corrosion resistance.14,15 While the Ru oxide generally shows a higher activity, the Ir oxide exhibits a better long-term stability.16-18 Many strategies concerning the synthesis of these anode materials by different chemical or physical ways were reported, such as nano oxides,19 bulk oxides,20 thin layers,21,22 and supported nano oxides.23-25 However, the challenge in concurrently achieving highly active and long-term stable catalysts still remains to date. At present, the Ir-Ru bimetallic catalysts acquired are mainly in alloy structure, the improvement of catalytic performance for Ir-Ru oxides catalysts for OER were intensively researched and the trade off between stability and activity were widely explored.2628 Generally, an inverse correlation between activity and stability for the alloyed Ir-Ru catalysts is observed, and Ru “stabilization” by Ir is often realized by protecting less-noble Ru atoms by burying it under the Ir protective layer.28,29 Therefore, the realization of both high activity and stability requires strict and complex adjustment of the surface composition for the alloy catalysts. As an alternative to forming the alloy structure, the RuO2 supporting IrO2 may offer a new solution to addressing the activity-stability problem. Due to the similar particle scales of IrO2 and RuO2, IrO2 can be readily formed with surface-enriched structure and acts as the protective layer, meanwhile, the minor RuO2 exposed surface sites function as catalytic activity booster.

sections.heading: COMMUNICATION Journal Name
sections.text:
2 | J. Name., 2012, 00, 1-3 This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
Herein, uncontinuously covered IrO2 supported on RuO2@Ru nanocatalysts were designed and successfully fabricated to integrate the corresponding advantages of IrO2 and RuO2. Specifically, IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst possesses enhanced OER performance, the overpotential required for 10 mA cm-2 is only 281 mV with excellent durability in strongly acidic solution, and the intrinsic activity is enhanced by 0.7 and 1.3 times in comparison to the alloyed Ir3RuO2 and home-made IrO2 catalysts, respectively. These results indicate the highly promising application potential of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru oxide catalysts for OER.
As shown in Scheme 1, the synthesis of IrO2-RuO2@Ru catalysts was firstly proceeded by the reduction of RuCl3 to metallic Ru, then the Ru acted as “support” for the H2IrCl6 precursor, finally, supported IrO2-RuO2@Ru can be obtained through hydrolysis and thermal treatment (see ESI for preparation details). At the same time, Ir3RuO2 alloy oxide and pure IrO2 were prepared through similar method for comparison.

sections.heading: Results and discussion
sections.text:
The morphology and structural features of the thus achieved
catalysts were firstly investigated by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). As we can see from TEM and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images (Fig. 1a-f and S1), the dispersion of nanoparticles gets better with the Ir/Ru ratio changes from 1:1 to 3:1, and IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits the most uniform nanoparticle distribution among these catalysts, which is beneficial for improving the utilization of active sites. To further examine the element distribution within the Ir-Ru catalysts, highangle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) was performed. The element mapping was done on a randomly selected area, and a typical result illustrates the similar distribution states of Ir and Ru elements for both Ir3RuO2 and IrO2-RuO2@Ru catalyst (Fig. 1g-h and S2), indicating the even distributions of IrO2 on RuO2 for the supported catalysts. In addition, the atomic ratios of Ir/Ru obtained from EDX results agree well with the nominal Ir/Ru ratios in the feeding solutions (Fig. S3), demonstrating that no loss of Ir and Ru occurred during the whole preparation procedure.
N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms (Fig. 2a) were acquired to probe the specific surface areas (SSAs) of the catalysts. It can be seen that the supported structure is beneficial for improving the SSA, and IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits the highest SSA of 132.2 m2 g1, obviously higher than the Ir3RuO2 catalyst with 93.8 m2 g-1 (Fig. 2b). Combined with the relatively uniform nanoparticles distribution, the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst exhibits improved active sites, which favors the catalytic activity enhancement towards OER. Fig. 2c shows the characteristic diffraction peak positions of the varied catalysts. It is noted that IrO2 (tetragonal) and RuO2 (tetragonal) exhibit adjacent diffraction patterns (JCPDS No. 15-0870 and 40-1290), thus making it difficult to distinguish the two diffraction peaks. However, for the IrO2-RuO2@Ru catalysts, relatively weak diffraction peaks corresponding to (100), (002), (101) and (103) crystal planes of Ru (hexagonal; JCPDS No. 06-0663) can be recognized, due to the partial oxidation of surface Ru during the oxidation heat treatment. The remained metallic core of RuO2@Ru was further confirmed by the result from Fig. S4, where the mixture status of metal and oxide is observed after oxidizing
metallic Ru. So far, it can be concluded that three components constitute the final IrO2-RuO2@Ru catalysts, namely IrO2, RuO2 and Ru. The final structure of the corresponding catalysts can be described as IrO2 anchored on RuO2 coated on Ru, as shown in Scheme 1. For the Ir3RuO2 catalyst, the diffraction peak of (110) crystal plane (28.033°) locates between the values for IrO2 (28.054°) and RuO2 (28.009°), suggesting the formation of alloy structure (Fig. 2d).
The surface analysis was carried out by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). A comparison of the survey spectra for these catalysts is shown in Fig. 3a, by comparing the photoelectron lines for the samples, it clearly appears that no impurities are present on the surface. The Ru 3p signal varies greatly between IrO2-RuO2@Ru and Ir3RuO2. Specifically, although the similar Ir/Ru ratios of IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1) and Ir3RuO2 were confirmed by EDX, the Ru 3p signal in the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst is obviously much weaker than that in the Ir3RuO2 (Fig. S5), indicating that the majority of Ru is buried under IrO2. This is confirmed by data shown in Table S1, as the nominal Ir/Ru ratio of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) is 3:1, while the actual value of 6.23:1 was detected by XPS. For Ir3RuO2 catalyst, however, the actual Ir/Ru ratio (2.91:1) is similar to the stoichiometry. The high resolution Ru 3p3/2 spectra were deconvoluted into two peaks (Fig. 3c-f), corresponding to Ru (0) and Ru (IV)-RuO2, respectively, with the fitted results shown in Table S2. Specifically, the content of Ru (0) in IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1 55.8%) catalyst is obviously higher than that in Ir3RuO2 (33.1%), owing to the IrO2-enriched surface structure. The Ir 4f spectra are shown in Fig. 3b, the Ir 4f7/2 binding energies of IrO2-RuO2@Ru are the same to IrO2, demonstrating that IrO2 and RuO2 only hold a supporting relation, and there is no electron-interaction between IrO2 and RuO2. By contrast, the Ir 4f7/2 orbit binding energy of Ir3RuO2 decreases by 0.30 eV in comparison to other catalysts, indicating the electronic structure of Ir has been altered, which is resulted from the formation of alloy structure. These results are well consistent with the XRD characterization.
The varied catalysts acquired were characterized through cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements in acidic solution. As shown in Fig. S6a, the CV shapes exhibit broad waves, resulting from the solidstate redox reactions accompanied by proton exchange between the oxide and the electrolyte.25,30 The anodic to cathodic charge ratios (Qa/Qc) for all the thus achieved catalysts are close to 1.0 by integrating the voltammograms of various scanning rates (2 to 300 mV s-1) (Fig. S6b), confirming the excellent reversibility of the catalysts.31 Furthermore, the outer charge (QO) and total charge (QT) of the catalysts can be calculated by integrating the voltammograms taken at the scanning rates of 300 and 2 mV s−1, respectively.32,33 The former shows the outer and more accessible active surface during OER while the latter shows the whole active surface. It is visualized that IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) possesses the largest outer charge (Fig. S6c), therefore, the highest number of accessible active sites. The QO : QT ratios of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (1:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (2:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (4:1), IrO2 and Ir3RuO2 are 44.8, 59.7, 64.8, 57.2, 48.1 and 51.4% (Fig. S6d), respectively, demonstrating that IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) not only possesses the highest utilization of active sites, but also the most effective proton diffusion. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves (the integration of dashed lines from Fig. S7; iR-corrected) show

sections.text:
This journal is © The Royal Society of Chemistry 20xx J. Name., 2013, 00, 1-3 | 3
Please do not adjust margins
Please do not adjust margins
that IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits the highest activity among all the catalysts (Fig. 4a). Specifically, the overpotentials needed to attain the current density of 0.5, 1, 5 and 10 mA cm-2 are only 211, 227, 266 and 281 mV, respectively. Especially, the overpotential at 10 mA cm-2 for IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) is lower by 12 and 36 mV in comparison to the Ir3RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts (Table S3), respectively, which is also superior to the commercial IrO2 (CM) and RuO2 (CM) catalysts with the overpotential lowered by 37 and 8 mV, respectively. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) were calculated to assess the intrinsic activity of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1), Ir3RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts. The TOF values of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1), Ir3RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts are ca. 0.039, 0.023 and 0.017 s-1 at 1.55 V, respectively, indicating that IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits higher intrinsic activity than other catalysts and the active sites on the catalyst surface possess greater ability to generate oxygen. Hence, the intrinsic activity of the active sites combined of Ir and Ru atoms can be effectively improved with this supported structure of IrO2RuO2@Ru type catalysts. LSV curves (without iR-corrected) of IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1) with different catalyst loadings are shown in Fig. 4b. To obtain the comparative catalytic activities for OER, the catalyst loading needed for IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) is only 0.100 mg cm-2, while it needs as high as 0.379 mg cm-2 for IrO2 (Table S4). Hence, up to 73.6 percent of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst can be saved to obtain the comparative catalytic effect with IrO2, which exhibits huge advantage in saving the precious metals for water electrolysis. Furthermore, IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst exhibits comparable or even better catalytic activity with the reported catalysts shown in Table S5, especially the Ir-Ru alloy catalysts, the overpotentials of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) are obviously lower than the Ru0.8Ir0.2O2 (>320 mV@10 mA cm-2),17 Ir0.5Ru0.5O2 (~320 mV@10 mA cm-2),34 and Ir0.5Ru0.5O2/ATO (240 mV@1 mA cm-2)25 catalysts with the similar catalyst loadings (Table S4 and S5).
The mechanism of reaction process was studied by the iRcorrected Tafel plots fitted from LSV curves (Fig. 4c). Here S is an active site of the oxide electrocatalyst while S-OH* represents an intermediate that precedes the formation of S-OH, S-OH* and S-OH have the same chemical structure but different energy states due to a different bond strength to the active site.1,35 The Tafel slopes (from 53.1 mV dec-1 to 57.3 mV dec-1; Table S6) of these catalysts are around 60 mV dec-1, indicating that the steps combination of R11 and R1-2 as the rate determining steps for all the catalysts.1,35,36 Moreover, the Tafel slope of IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) is relatively smaller than other catalysts, indicating the faster kinetics rate for

sections.heading: OER.
sections.text:
Acidic Mechanism: S + H2O → S-OH* + H+ + e- (R1-1) S-OH* → S-OH (R1-2) S-OH → S-O + H+ + e- (R2) S-O + S-O → 2S + O2 (R3)
Next, the EIS were applied to further study the characteristic of reaction kinetics (Fig. 4d). The equivalent circuit (EC) was used to fit the measured EIS. It can be concluded from the EC that each EIS exhibits two sections in which the (Rf, Qf) pair is associated with the physical processes of the oxide layer at higher frequencies and the (Rct, Qdl) pair is associated with the electrochemical processes at the reaction interface at relatively lower frequencies.37 In the EC, Rs is the uncompensated solution resistance, the components Rf and Qf
should represent the resistive and capacitive behaviors of the oxides, respectively, the components Rct and Qdl refer to the charge transfer resistance and the electric double layer capacitance, respectively. The Rs for IrO2-RuO2@Ru (1:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (2:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (4:1), IrO2, Ir3RuO2, IrO2 (CM) and RuO2 (CM) are 3.24, 3.22, 2.45, 2.88, 3.22, 2.48, 2.67 and 2.63 Ω, respectively; these values are used to compensate solution resistance. Furthermore, the charge transfer resistance of IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1) is only 14.94 Ω, smaller than the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (1:1) (28.54 Ω), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (2:1) (19.36 Ω), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (4:1) (23.22 Ω), IrO2 (26.65 Ω), Ir3RuO2 (20.48 Ω), IrO2 (CM; 27.48 Ω), and RuO2 (CM; 20.17 Ω) catalysts, indicating the fastest charge transfer rate on the electrode, in favor of enhancing the electrocatalytic performance for OER. The performance degradation during chronoamperometry tests of the as-prepared catalysts are displayed in Fig. 4e. All of the catalysts show obvious loss in OER activity during the initial period and reach a relatively stable state during the latter period. Among them, IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits an obviously lower activity decay rate than Ir3RuO2 and other catalysts, attributing to the superiority of IrO2-enriched surface and supported structure.
Based on the aforementioned results, a two-electrode configuration for overall water splitting was employed with IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1), Ir3RuO2 or IrO2 as anodic catalyst while the Pt/C as cathodic catalyst, respectively. The results shown in Fig. 4f verify the high catalytic activity of the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst with the overpotentials at 10 mA cm-2 and 100 mA cm-2 are 259 mV and 567 mV, respectively, which are lower by 8, 56 mV and 28, 91 mV in comparison to the Ir3RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts, respectively.
The accelerated durability tests (ADTs) were performed to further assess the durability of all the as-prepared catalysts by applying cyclic potential sweeps between 1.10 and 1.70 V at a sweep rate of 50 mV/s for 3000 cycles. As shown in Fig. 5, the overpotentials at 10 mA cm-2 positively shifts by 44, 33, 16, 22, 25, 37, 29 and 59 mV for IrO2-RuO2@Ru (1:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (2:1), IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1), IrO2-RuO2@Ru (4:1), IrO2, Ir3RuO2, IrO2 (CM) and RuO2 (CM) catalysts, respectively. It is clearly shown that IrO2RuO2@Ru (3:1) exhibits enhanced durability. Furthermore, inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES) was used to determine the quantity of Ir, Ru dissolution after the ADTs. It is obvious that the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst possesses the lowest Ir, Ru dissolution percentage of only ca. 8.3 at% and 14.2 at% in comparison to the original Ir and Ru components (Table S7), respectively, indicating the advantage of IrO2-enriched surface and supported structure, which is in favor of maintaining the excellent catalytic performance during the OER.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text:
In summary, we successfully synthesized uncontinuously
covered IrO2-RuO2@Ru nanocatalysts and effectively combined the RuO2 activity and the IrO2 stability. The as-prepared catalysts exhibit IrO2-enriched surface and supported structure. Among them, the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst possesses more uniform particle distribution, higher specific surface area, much lower charge transfer resistance, lower oxygen evolution overpotential and higher durability in comparison to other catalysts for the OER in

acidic media. Moreover, the IrO2-RuO2@Ru (3:1) catalyst exhibits huge advantage in saving the noble metals for water electrolysis. Hence, the supported Iridium-Ruthenium bimetallic oxides can be regarded as ideal candidates for oxygen evolution reaction.
